et: Middle English {it}yerd,{/it} going back to Old English {it}geard{/it} "fence, enclosure, dwelling, home, district, country," going back to Germanic {it}*garđa-{/it} (whence also Old Saxon {it}gard{/it} "garden, dwelling, world," Middle Dutch {it}gaert{/it} "garden, yard," Old High German {it}gart{/it} "enclosure, circle, enclosed piece of property," Old Norse {it}garðr{/it} "enclosure, courtyard," Gothic {it}gards{/it} (i-stem) "house, household, courtyard"; from an n-stem {it}*garđan-{/it}: Old Frisian {it}garda{/it} "family property, courtyard," Old Saxon {it}gardo{/it} "garden," Old High German {it}garto{/it}), perhaps (if from {it}*ghortós{/it}) going back to Indo-European {it}*ghortos{/it} "enclosure," whence also Old Irish {it}gort{/it} "arable or pasture field," Welsh {it}garth{/it} "field, enclosure, fold," Breton {it}garz{/it} "hedge," Latin {it}hortus{/it} "garden," Greek {it}chórtos{/it} "farmyard, pasturage"

The above is only one possible account of this somewhat problematic etymon. If not from a Verner's Law variant of a putative stem {it}*ghor-to-,{/it} the Germanic word could go back to {it}*ghordho-,{/it} which would correspond to Slavic {it}*gordŭ{/it} (Old Church Slavic {it}gradŭ{/it} "town, garden, yard," Russian {it}górod{/it} "city," Bosnian-Croatian-Serbian {it}grâd{/it}) and Lithuanian {it}gar͂das{/it} "pen, fold." The Slavic and Baltic words have, alternatively, been taken as loans from Germanic. This explanation would not, however, cover Albanian {it}gardh{/it} "fence, wattled partition," or, more crucially, Sanskrit {it}gṛháḥ{/it} "house," if it goes back to {it}*ghr̥dhos,{/it} a zero-grade derivative. The Germanic etymon has traditionally been connected with a hypothetical verb base {it}*ǵher-{/it} "grasp, enclose," seen in Sanskrit {it}harati{/it} "(s/he) takes, fetches, bears," {it}jahrur{/it} "were fetched," though the Albanian, Balto-Slavic and Sanskrit words do not show a palatovelar. A palatovelar is evidenced, however, in a group of semantically related words: Lithuanian {it}žárdas{/it} "rack for drying grain, flax or pease, cattle hurdle," {it}ža͂rdis{/it} "fenced pasture," Old Prussian {it}sardis{/it} "fence," regional Russian {it}zoród, zaród{/it} "stack of hay or grain sheaves, enclosure around a stack." Also associated with Germanic {it}*garđa-{/it} is a strong verb {it}*gerđan-{/it} hypothetically evidenced by Gothic {it}*-gairdan{/it} (attested only as the past participle {it}bigaurdans,{/it} translating Greek {it}perizōsámenos{/it} "girding oneself") and a weak verb {it}*gurdjan-{/it} with zero grade—see {et_link|gird:1|gird:1}, {et_link|girdle:1|girdle:1}, {et_link|girth:1|girth:1}.

pt: {sc}standard{/sc} {sc}criterion{/sc} {sc}gauge{/sc} {sc}yardstick{/sc} {sc}touchstone{/sc} mean a means of determining what a thing should be. {sc}standard{/sc} applies to any definite rule, principle, or measure established by authority.
{sc}criterion{/sc} may apply to anything used as a test of quality whether formulated as a rule or principle or not.
{sc}gauge{/sc} applies to a means of testing a particular dimension (such as thickness, depth, diameter) or figuratively a particular quality or aspect.

pt.t: polls as a {it}gauge{/it} of voter dissatisfaction

pt: {sc}yardstick{/sc} is an informal substitute for {sc}criterion{/sc} that suggests quantity more often than quality.

pt.t: housing construction as a {it}yardstick{/it} of economic growth

pt: {sc}touchstone{/sc} suggests a simple test of the authenticity or value of something intangible.

pt.t: fine service is one {it}touchstone{/it} of a first-class restaurant

pt: {sc}yield{/sc} {sc}submit{/sc} {sc}capitulate{/sc} {sc}succumb{/sc} {sc}relent{/sc} {sc}defer{/sc} mean to give way to someone or something that one can no longer resist. {sc}yield{/sc} may apply to any sort or degree of giving way before force, argument, persuasion, or entreaty.
{sc}submit{/sc} suggests full surrendering after resistance or conflict to the will or control of another.

pt.t: a repentant sinner vowing to {it}submit{/it} to the will of God

pt: {sc}capitulate{/sc} stresses the fact of ending all resistance and may imply either a coming to terms (as with an adversary) or hopelessness in the face of an irresistible opposing force.
{sc}succumb{/sc} implies weakness and helplessness to the one that gives way or an overwhelming power to the opposing force.

pt.t: a stage actor {it}succumbing{/it} to the lure of Hollywood

pt: {sc}relent{/sc} implies a yielding through pity or mercy by one who holds the upper hand.

pt.t: finally {it}relented{/it} and let the children stay up late

pt: {sc}defer{/sc} implies a voluntary yielding or submitting out of respect or reverence for or deference and affection toward another.

pt.t: I {it}defer{/it} to your expertise in these matters
